issues.text: Whether the direction in the earlier award was given without jurisdiction by travelling outside the terms of reference?

anchor.surface_text: Industrial Tribunals which deal with industrial disputes referred to them under s. 10(1)(d) of the Act are, in a sense, Tribunals with limited jurisdiction. holdings.text: the applications made by the respondents were competent and the Labour Court had jurisdiction to deal with the question as to the computation of the benefit conferred on the respondents in terms of money.

anchor.surface_text: That decision shows that the applications made by the respondents were competent and the Labour Court had jurisdiction to deal with the question as to the computation of the benefit conferred on the respondents in terms of money.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on precedent in Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P.S. Rajagopalan holding s.33C(2) allows computation of benefits under prior awards.

holdings.text: the Labour Court under s. 33C(2) would be competent to interpret the award on which the claim is based, and it would also be open to it to consider the plea that the award sought to be enforced is a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: the labour Court under s. 33C 2 would be competent to interpret the award on which the claim is based, and it would also be open to it to consider the plea that the award sought to be enforced is a nullity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to executing court in CPC proceedings; can refuse null awards as principle applies to s.33C(2).

holdings.text: the impugned direction has relation not to demand No. 11 b , but to demand No. 11 a , and it is obvious that demand referred to all workers and was not confined to any specified categories of workers.

anchor.surface_text: on a careful examination of the scheme of the award in so far as it relates to demand No. 11, it would be clear that the impugned direction has relation not to demand No. 11 b , but to demand No. 11 a , and it is obvious that demand referred to all workers and was not confined to any specified categories of workers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of award scheme; direction under 11(a) covering all workers, 'and others' justified.

holdings.text: the relief granted by the Tribunal in paragraph 115 of its award has reference to demand No. 11 a and the use of the words and others is not only not outside the terms of reference, but is quite appropriate and justified.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the relief granted by the Tribunal in paragraph 115 of its award has reference. to demand No. 11 a  and the use of the words and others is not only not outside the terms of reference, but is quite appropriate and justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of award shows coverage of qualifying workers including 'and others'; within terms of reference.

holdings.text: the test which has to be satisfied by the workers is that they could have been required to work on Sundays in that year... the test is did the terms and conditions of service impose an obligation on the workers to attend duties on Sundays if called upon to do so?

anchor.surface_text: The said clause does not provide that before getting the benefit in question, the workers must show that they actually worked on all Sundays in the year. The test which has to be satisfied by the workers is that they could have been required to work on Sundays in that year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misconstruction by appellant; Labour Court finding on Ext.32 upheld; obligation if required, not actual work every Sunday.

holdings.text: where the legislature has made no provision for limitation, it would not be open to the courts to introduce any such limitation on grounds of fairness or justice. The words of s. 33C(2) are plain and unambiguous and it would be the duty of the Labour Court to give effect to the said provision without any considerations of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that where the legislature has made no provision for limitation, it would not be open to the courts to introduce any such limitation on grounds of fairness or justice. The words of s. 33C 2  are plain and unambiguous and it would be the duty of the Labour Court to give effect to the said provision without any considerations of limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate omission despite knowledge of PWA; cannot import limitation or laches; unlike bonus claims.

holdings.text: art. 181 applies only to applications which are made under the Code of Civil Procedure, and so, its extension to applications made under s. 33C(2) of the Act would not be justified.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that art. 181 applies only to applications which are made under the Code of Civil Procedure, and so, its extension to applications made under s. 33C 2  of the Act would not be justified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled law from precedents like Bombay High Court, Privy Council, Supreme Court; only for CPC apps.

holdings.text: the Labour Court was right in rejecting the appellants contention that since the present claim was belated, it should not be awarded.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds rejection of laches; distinguishes from bonus; execution-like, no equity bar.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that where the legislature has made no provision for limitation, it would not be open to the courts to introduce any such limitation on grounds of fairness or justice. The words of s. 33C 2  are plain and unambiguous and it would be the duty of the Labour Court to give effect to the said provision without any considerations of limitation.
Therefore, we think, that the Labour Court was right in rejecting the appellants contention that since the present claim was belated, it should not be awarded.
